non-binding contract it's a document that has a handful of terms that
basically outlines what will happen in an investment and so usually it's the
piece of paper two pieces of paper and some instances ten pieces of paper that you'll use to define the parameters of

step back and and think about like why term sheets exist so so as a venture capital investor we get money from
people we call limited partners and may basically trust us with their capital to deploy and steward hoping that there
will be a return on their investment and so when they give us capital we agree to a handful of commitments and obligations
that we will pay attention to where that capital goes we'll put kind of restrictions rights
and protections in place so we can protect that investment throughout the lifecycle of a company and so so really
a term sheet is a list of rights and protections that investors have it really comes into play when things go
poorly and when things go well usually the terms don't really matter don't really talk too much about the
terms it's it's a set of kind of rules and obligations for when things go poorly I think one thing that's
important to think about with the term sheet is it's really an opportunity for the investor and the founder to be
aligned over certain elements it's so we're kind of continuing to have the
same incentives to row the boat in the direction in the same direction which is to build a very powerful and successful
and massive business so there are all sorts of terms in there that that that
accomplish that I think you know there are a number of good terms so on one hand a term would be assembling a board

equity carved out for employees these are all really good things kind of on the negative side as a protection for
investors there are things like voting rights which mean as a founder you can't
